newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Colombo stocks end flat, all eyes on estate firms.
newsitem.headline: Colombo stocks end flat, all eyes on estate firms.

text.p: Sri Lankan stocks ended barely changed on Tuesday when institutions focused their attention to the sale of a controlling stake in a plantation firm being privatised, brokers said.
The Colombo Stock Exchange all share index closed 0.14 points higher at 556.44. NDB, a development finance institution rose one rupee to 191 and Tea Services three rupees to 63.
"Trading was very thin because we were unable to source shares in bulk," said Ralph Wijesinghe of Asia Securities.
Turnover was 6.22 million rupees with 183,750 shares changing hands.
With the index strongly supported at around the 550 level, brokers said virtually no one wanted to liquidate holdings.
Investors were keenly watching biddings on Hapugastenne Plantations, for which the government was selling a 51 percent stake on the bourse as part of its privatisation campaign.
The parcel was bought by a local constortium for 23.75 rupees a share, brokers said. This raised 242.25 million rupees.
The government said it would also sell a 51 percent stake in Balangod Plantations, another estate firm. Bids close on September 12. -- Prithi Kodagoda 941-434319
